intro: Senecio valdivianus, commonly known as the Valdivian groundsel, is a flowering plant native to the temperate rainforests of South America, particularly in Chile and Argentina. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and milky sap. The plant typically grows as a low shrub, reaching heights of up to 1 meter, with dark green, hairy leaves and yellow flowers that bloom in the spring. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is adapted to the cool, humid climate of its native habitat. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
